author: By Mekado Murphy
title: Watch an Emotional Reunion in ‘Past Lives’
description: The writer and director Celine Song narrates a sequence from her film featuring Greta Lee and Teo Yoo.
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Stephen Kotkin. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross, Sarah Kerr and Adam Dean
title: A Visual Timeline of the Protests in France
description: Clashes between protesters and police continued in cities across France. “We don’t forget, we don’t forgive,” crowds chanted.
content: The fatal shooting of a French teenager of Algerian and Moroccan descent by a police officer has set off days of violent protests that have rocked France.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Study Finds Rise in Texas Births After Abortion Law. But Questions Remain.
description: A year after Dobbs, researchers are still trying to answer a central question: How many more babies are born as a result of abortion bans?
content: For more than a year, since the U.S. Supreme Court’s decision overturning Roe v. Wade, pregnant women have faced a radically altered landscape of challenges and choices as the number of abortion providers dropped to zero in more than a dozen states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Here’s what will happen to your student loans now.
description: The pandemic pause on student loan payments will end soon, but a new system for calculating repayments may lower monthly bills.
content: Now that the Supreme Court has blocked President Biden’s student debt cancellation proposal, people with loan balances have two things to watch in the short term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Judson Jones
title: As the South Stews, Temperatures Are Set to Rise in the West, Too
description: In the South, oppressive temperatures are expected to continue through Sunday in southern Texas and places along the Gulf of Mexico. Out West, an arid heat will take hold.
content: When forecasters predicted that oppressive heat would settle over much of the South for days this month, one of the first thoughts for staff members at the Mobile Botanical Gardens was how to protect their most sensitive plants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: A Bond Built Over Coffee Leads to Success in Love and Business
description: Sahra Nguyen and Erics Kun’s connection grew slowly during early morning meetups at Brooklyn cafes. Now, they are partners in life and at Nguyen Coffee Supply, founded by Ms. Nguyen.
content: Erics Kun was fighting yawns the first few times he and Sahra Nguyen got together in the fall of 2016. This was no reflection on her. After staying up all night in his bartending job, he couldn’t pass up the chance to see her for early morning coffee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: Trump, Crossing Paths With DeSantis, Tries to Outflank Him
description: At a gathering of right-wing activists, Donald Trump vowed to target federal diversity programs and to use the Justice Department to investigate schools and corporations over supposed racial discrimination.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump moved on Friday to outflank Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida as they wrestled for conservative loyalties at a gathering of right-wing activists in Philadelphia, pushing a shared agenda of forcing the federal government to the right, restricting transgender rights and limiting how race and L.G.B.T.Q. issues are taught.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Hicks, Megan Specia and Gaëlle Girbes
title: Russia Destroyed Their Town. They’re Not Leaving.
description: Avdiivka, Ukraine, once had a prewar population of about 30,000. By March, only around 1,700 people remained.
content: In the town of Avdiivka, in eastern Ukraine, the near-constant Russian shelling has reduced the city to rubble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Everdeen Mason
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: The Court Delivers Another Reassuring Decision for Religious Conservatives
description: Allowing a web designer to refuse to provide services for same-sex marriages follows other recent rulings that have been cheered by the Christian right.
content: Conservatives who have moral and theological objections to gay marriage saw the Supreme Court’s decision on Friday as reassurance that they would be able to assert their beliefs in a public square that they see as increasingly hostile to them.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Debate Over Affirmative Action Isn’t Over
description: Reader offer a range of reactions to the Supreme Court ruling. Also: Do the justices have any regrets over their Dobbs decision?
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anderson Tepper
title: New International Fiction: Dark Histories, Daunting Labors
description: Novels and stories by Itamar Vieira Junior, Carlos Fonseca, Guadalupe Nettel and Norman Erikson Pasaribu.
content: CROOKED PLOW (Verso, 276 pp., paperback, $19.95), by the Afro-Brazilian author Itamar Vieira Junior (and translated by Johnny Lorenz), offers a salt-of-the-earth paean to a land where “the blood of history flows like a river.” Life is hard on the Água Negra plantation in northeastern Brazil in the mid-20th century — an endless cycle of drought and floods, the shadows of slavery still hanging heavily on the tenant farmers who eke out an existence. “Suffering was the secret blood running through the veins of Água Negra,” we’re told.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Mark Halpin returns with a quiet acrostic that resonates.
content: ACROSTIC — Today’s puzzle, constructed by Mark Halpin, draws from a hefty historical novel called “Wolf Hall,” by Hilary Mantel, which won the Man Booker Prize in 2009. The book is the first in a trilogy that provides a fictional portrait of Thomas Cromwell, who was chief minister to King Henry VIII from 1534 until Cromwell’s demise by beheading in 1540. An awful lot happened in those six years, much of which is depicted in “Wolf Hall” and its sequels, “Bring Up the Bodies” and “The Mirror and the Light.” There were battles, there were more beheadings and there was a plague — the kinds of things that provide context for this acrostic’s excerpt, which concerns loss and a sort of sensory residue that loss leaves behind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: How Christians and Drag Queens Are Defending the First Amendment
description: The Supreme Court reaffirms freedom of speech — and the freedom not to speak.
content: I’m mostly done with my legal career. In 2015, after more than 20 years of full-time litigation, I hung up my courtroom spurs and moved into the world of writing and thinking for a living. But every now and then, I re-enter the fray. Last year I wrote an amicus brief in a case called 303 Creative L.L.C. v. Elenis, arguing that a wedding website designer had a First Amendment right not to speak. And on Friday the Supreme Court reached a decision in the case, ruling for the website designer and holding that the State of Colorado could not require her to design websites that, for example, celebrated same-sex weddings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh and Alyssa Schukar
title: Shattered Nerves, Sleepless Nights: Pickleball Noise Is Driving Everyone Nuts
description: The incessant pop-pop-pop of the fast-growing sport has brought on a nationwide scourge of unneighborly clashes, petitions, calls to the police and lawsuits, with no solution in sight.
content: It sounded like popcorn warming in a microwave: sporadic bursts that quickened, gradually, to an arrhythmic clatter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Saimin Noodles, Pork and Vegetable Pinakbet and Mochiko Chicken
description: New recipes for Hawaiian local food favorites are comforting, versatile and deeply delicious.
content: Good morning. Elyse Inamine has a cool story in our pages this week about “local food” in Hawaii, food that reflects the blurred culture of all those who’ve settled on the islands over the centuries, from Polynesian settlers, British and American plantation owners and laborers from China, Japan, Korea, the Philippines, Puerto Rico, Portugal and Spain. Local food is the food of the future, some in Hawaii say, an amalgamation of all that is delicious: the food local people eat, and revere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: French Thinker
description: Carly Schuna’s second New York Times crossword makes me look forward to their third.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By McKenna Oxenden
title: ‘Now, Let’s Be a Starfish!’: Learning With Ms. Rachel, Song by Song
description: The YouTube star of “Songs for Littles,” an online video series that pulls millions of views, says she’s found her calling in encouraging children to speak.
content: Rachel Griffin Accurso was rushing to grab pastries on her way to a recording studio one spring morning in Manhattan. She grew hot as she left the subway with the sun beating down on her, and she took her jacket off without thinking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: If You Think Shohei Ohtani Is Versatile, Look Up Monte Ward
description: Having thrown baseball’s second perfect game keeps John Montgomery Ward’s name alive. But the pitcher, shortstop, golfer, lawyer and author was not content with perfection.
content: Any time a pitcher throws a perfect game, as Domingo Germán of the Yankees did on Wednesday, the list of previous pitchers who performed the feat is trotted out. The names are famous (Sandy Koufax! Cy Young!) and decidedly less famous (Dallas Braden?).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Judge to Decide Whether Taint of C.I.A. Torture Extended to Guantánamo
description: At issue is whether an alleged confession made at the naval base but after years in C.I.A. black sites can be used against a man accused of bombing the U.S.S. Cole.
content: More than 22 years after Al Qaeda bombed the U.S.S. Cole and nearly 12 years after a prisoner was first charged with plotting the attack, a judge heard final arguments Friday on a fundamental question in the pretrial phase of the case: Can the accused bomber’s confession, after years in C.I.A. custody, be used against him?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evgeny Morozov
title: The True Threat of Artificial Intelligence
description: Technology forged by private markets won’t solve the world’s problems. It will only amplify them.
content: In May, more than 350 technology executives, researchers and academics signed a statement warning of the existential dangers of artificial intelligence. “Mitigating the risk of extinction from A.I. should be a global priority alongside other societal-scale risks such as pandemics and nuclear war,” the signatories warned.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 16 Songs to Soundtrack Your Fourth of July Barbecue
description: Listen to a genre-crossing hourlong summer playlist featuring Lana Del Rey, Funkadelic and Tom Petty.
content: At last, the season of late sunsets, languid beach days and endless barbecues is upon us. This calls for a playlist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Bracing for New Night of Unrest, Macron Urges Parents to Keep Teenagers Home
description: Over 800 people were arrested in France after a fresh wave of nighttime protests over the fatal police shooting of a 17-year-old. Many protesters were teenagers, too, officials said.
content: President Emmanuel Macron of France urgently appealed to parents on Friday as the country braced for another night of unrest over the fatal police shooting of a 17-year-old, with French officials saying that the protests were driven mostly by angry young people and coordinated on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: For a Documentary on Intersex Lives, a Director Champions the Power of Activism
description: With “Every Body,” Julie Cohen looks at both what her subjects have been through and how they are translating those experiences into action.
content: The new documentary “Every Body” gets intimate with its subjects, from their birth records to their body parts. The film is about being intersex, an umbrella term for people who were born with anatomic or genetic characteristics that don’t match the typical definition of male or female.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Supreme Court Turns ‘Equal Protection’ Upside Down
description: Its ruling on affirmative action in college admissions overturns decades of precedents and programs that helped thousands of American students.
content: In striking down affirmative action in higher education on Thursday, the Supreme Court’s conservative majority said it had to do so because the Constitution forbids any form of racial distinction. With a single opinion, the justices overturned decades of precedents that upheld race-conscious admissions policies as consistent with the 14th Amendment’s equal protection clause and ignored the reality of modern America, where prejudice and racism endure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Michael J. de la Merced and Lauren Hirsch
title: Why Corporate America Is Worried About Affirmative Action
description: Many businesses have adopted policies to diversify hiring but the Supreme Court’s ruling to end the policy in universities endangers those efforts.
content: The Supreme Court’s decision on Thursday to strike down affirmative action at colleges and universities sent shock waves throughout higher education. But the effects of the 6-3 ruling, which found that race-conscious admissions programs were unlawful, promise to go much wider.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: Why Buy Anything You Could Borrow (Especially If You’re Renting)?
description: The sharing economy has come to apartment buildings — and landlords have discovered a new way to attract tenants.
content: Brooke Renteria moved to a studio in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, from California two years ago. All she had to unpack were her suitcases. The unit of less than 400 square feet in Caesura, an apartment building cater-corner from the Brooklyn Academy of Music, came with a Murphy bed, a built-in table/desk and a 49-inch smart TV.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: What the Affirmative Action Ruling Means for Colleges and Universities
description: The end of race-conscious admissions could have wide-ranging effects. Here’s what might happen.
content: The Supreme Court’s decision to end race-conscious admissions will very likely change higher education in complicated ways. Some of them will be obvious, including immediate changes in the demographics of campus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Martell
title: To Unlock His Potential, He Needed to Come Home
description: Harrison Bader loved St. Louis but couldn’t thrive there. A weekend series between the Yankees and the Cardinals offers a reminder of a trade that helped both teams.
content: Minutes before Major League Baseball’s trading deadline last season, Paul DeJong, the shortstop for the St. Louis Cardinals, received a notification on his phone. It was a message in the team group chat from center fielder Harrison Bader, one of DeJong’s closest friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Highlights of the Student Loan Forgiveness Opinions and Dissent
description: The court’s Republican-appointed conservative majority ruled over the vigorous dissent of its three Democratic-appointed liberal justices. Here are some key excerpts.
content: The Supreme Court on Friday struck down the Biden administration’s massive student loan forgiveness program, ruling that the Education Department had exceeded the authority granted to it by Congress to alter loan conditions in a national emergency like the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

content: “I’m afraid for my children. I don’t worry about robbers. I worry about the Republic coming for them.”

title: The Student Loan Borrowers Who Will Continue to Struggle
description: Those who didn’t complete their degrees and many parents are among the borrowers likely to face challenging times ahead.
content: The Supreme Court has barred the Biden administration from carrying out its plan to extinguish up to $20,000 in federal student loan debt, and millions of borrowers will continue to struggle under the weight of their loans.

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Police Shooting in France Presents New Challenge for Macron
description: Protests over the fatal police shooting of a teenager come as President Emmanuel Macron seeks to restore a sense of calm after his pension overhaul ignited turbulence in the streets.
content: The deadly shooting of a teenager, a French citizen of Algerian and Moroccan descent, by a police officer outside Paris has ignited a wave of violent protest that once again confronts President Emmanuel Macron with turmoil in the streets and has revived accusations of endemic racism in France’s law enforcement agencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: Let’s Talk About Sex Drive
description: Have you experienced discrepancies in sexual desire, or do you have sexual-health related questions?
content: Hello, I’m Catherine Pearson, a reporter for The New York Times’s Well section, where I cover families and relationships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: The director of the C.I.A. called the Kremlin to make clear the U.S. had no tie to Wagner’s rebellion.
description: The Biden administration has taken pains to emphasize that it viewed the matter as an internal Russian affair.
content: William J. Burns, the C.I.A. director, called the leader of Russia’s foreign intelligence service after last week’s rebellion to assure the Kremlin that the United States had no involvement in it, according to a U.S. official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman
title: Inflation and Spending Cooled in May, a Glimmer of Good News for the Fed
description: The Federal Reserve is watching to see how much the economy is slowing as it tries to wrangle inflation. Fresh data offered hopeful hints.
content: Consumer spending slowed and the Federal Reserve’s preferred inflation gauge continued to moderate in May, the latest signs that the cool-down that policymakers have been aiming for is materializing — albeit more haltingly than they might prefer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: The Most Exciting Show in Baseball
description: It took less than three weeks for Elly De La Cruz, a Cincinnati Reds infielder, to establish himself, and his team, as a force to be reckoned with in the N.L. Central.
content: Elly De La Cruz was relaxing with a group of teammates in the visitors’ clubhouse at Camden Yards on Monday when news broke that he had been named the National League Player of the Week after only his 17th game in the big leagues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Kevin Spacey Called ‘Sexual Bully’ by Prosecutor in U.K. Trial
description: The prosecution outlined its case against the actor, who has pleaded not guilty to 12 sexual assault charges.
content: The actor Kevin Spacey is “a sexual bully” who “delights in making others feel powerless and uncomfortable,” a prosecutor told a British jury on Friday. Speaking at Southwark Crown Court, the prosecutor, Christine Agnew, outlined her case against the Academy Award-winning actor, who is on trial in London facing multiple charges of sexual assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Ways You Can Still Cancel Your Federal Student Loan Debt
description: The Supreme Court’s decision on student loan cancellation does not change programs that help public servants and low-income or disabled borrowers.
content: There are still plenty of ways to get your student debt wiped away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Tracking What Happened to Abortion Providers After the Dobbs Decision
description: A current list of clinics that had closed, altered services or relocated didn’t exist — so two Times reporters made one.
content: Amy Schoenfeld Walker, a reporter and graphics editor who covers abortion for The New York Times, spotted an article in March by Shalina Chatlani, a New York Times local investigative fellow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Sun Narin
title: Cambodian Ruler’s Facebook Account Goes Dark After Spat With Meta
description: Prime Minister Hun Sen, an avid user of the platform, had vowed to delete his account after Meta’s oversight board said he had used it to threaten political violence.
content: The usually very active Facebook account for Prime Minister Hun Sen of Cambodia appeared to have been deleted on Friday, a day after the oversight board for Meta, Facebook’s parent company, recommended that he be suspended from the platform for threatening political opponents with violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Ito
title: How ‘Nimona’ Helped Its Creator Explore His Emerging Identity
description: The graphic novelist ND Stevenson wrote the trans allegory long before he came out. When it was time to adapt it for a new film, he was ready to go further.
content: In the new Netflix animated film “Nimona,” the titular character makes its first appearance as a redheaded teenage girl before transforming into a charging rhino, then a grizzly, then a songbird and so on, with brief stopovers as a gorilla, an ostrich and an armadillo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: What is the HEROES Act?
description: Lawyers for the Biden administration told the Supreme Court that it could cancel billions of dollars in student debt because Congress had given it that authority using the HEROES Act in 2003.
content: Lawyers for the Biden administration told the Supreme Court that it could cancel hundreds of billions of dollars in student debt because Congress had given it that authority in the Higher Education Relief Opportunities for Students Act of 2003, which is usually called the HEROES Act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Affirmative Action Ruling May Upend Hiring Policies, Too
description: The Supreme Court decision on college admissions could lead companies to alter recruitment and promotion practices to pre-empt legal challenges.
content: As a legal matter, the Supreme Court’s rejection of race-conscious admissions in higher education does not in itself impede employers from pursuing diversity in the workplace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Rojas
title: ‘We Didn’t Start the Fire’ Is Updated for a New Generation
description: Fall Out Boy has picked up where Billy Joel left off.
content: Three decades have passed since Billy Joel released his hit single “We Didn’t Start the Fire,” a song that chronicled cultural and historical events from 1949 to 1989. Its rapid-fire lyrics took listeners through a time machine, with references to figures such as Harry Truman and Marilyn Monroe and events such as the Korean War and Woodstock. Now, Fall Out Boy has picked up where the song left off with an updated cover version.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Fox News Agrees to Pay $12 Million to Settle Hostile Workplace Suit
description: The settlement with a former producer, Abby Grossberg, is the latest development in a series of legal battles involving Fox.
content: Fox News has agreed to pay $12 million to Abby Grossberg, a former Fox News producer who had accused the network of operating a hostile and discriminatory workplace and of coercing her into providing false testimony in a deposition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: John Early Brings a Deliriously Over-the-Top Sensibility to Stand-Up
description: In his new Max special, “Now More Than Ever,” the comedian mixes cringe comedy and cabaret to dizzying effect.
content: John Early’s boundary-blurring new Max special, “Now More Than Ever,” has the perfect title. The hyperbole, salesmanship and euphony of the expression match his literate satirical persona. And it also hints at the main asset and flaw of his hour: the too-muchness of it all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: The Overturning of Affirmative Action, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Protecting Australia’s Most Charismatic Murder-Bird
description: Cassowaries play a critical role in the Australian ecosystem.
content: Meet an Australian supermodel for the ages: six feet tall with a sculptured visage, endless legs and piercing orange eyes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: ‘Rust’ Armorer Passed Off Cocaine After Shooting, Prosecutors Say
description: Prosecutors accused Hannah Gutierrez-Reed of transferring the drugs on the day the film’s cinematographer was killed. Her lawyer said she would plead not guilty.
content: Prosecutors in New Mexico said in a court filing Thursday that the armorer who loaded the gun on the set of the film “Rust” before it went off during a rehearsal, killing the cinematographer, transferred a small bag of cocaine to someone after she was interviewed by police on the day of the fatal shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Belle Burden
title: Was I Married to a Stranger?
description: I thought I knew my husband of 20 years. I didn’t — and still don’t.
content: When the lockdown started in March 2020, my husband and I decided to quarantine with our two youngest children, then 15 and 12, at our house on Martha’s Vineyard. We arrived on March 15 and settled in for a long stay, unpacking sweaters and boots, textbooks and cellos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Soccer’s Next Big Thing Is Buying in Bulk
description: Networks of clubs help top teams streamline their scouting, methods and player acquisition. But who do they really serve?
content: On Wednesday evening, the Colombian club Atlético Huila decided to treat its players and its coaching staff to what could be best thought of as an office night out. Huila has had a rough season. It finished at the bottom of the Apertura, the first half of the Colombian campaign. It won only five of its 20 games. A field trip was more a restorative than a reward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: Group Accuses Ukraine of Using Prohibited Land Mines
description: Human Rights Watch found evidence in May that Ukrainian soldiers had fired 15 rockets at Russian forces, each containing hundreds of small antipersonnel land mines.
content: Ukrainian soldiers fired artillery rockets containing antipersonnel land mines into a Russian-controlled area of eastern Ukraine last year in apparent violation of international agreements banning the use of such weapons, a leading human rights group said in a report released Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: The ground has shifted on gay marriage for conservative Christians.
description: Once a focus of the nation’s culture wars, the issue has taken a back seat to gender issues.
content: For decades, opposition to same-sex marriage was a marquee issue for the religious right in the United States. Activists like Anita Bryant, Jerry Falwell and James Dobson characterized homosexuality as a threat to traditional family life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison
title: The End of LIBOR Is (Finally) Here
description: It has been an arduous process to get the financial system to stop relying on the tarnished interest-rate benchmark.
content: The arduous, decade-long process to end the financial system’s reliance on a tarnished interest-rate benchmark, which once underpinned trillions of dollars in contracts across the globe, is almost over. From next week, the rate, known as the London Interbank Offered Rate, or LIBOR for short, will cease to be published.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Best Films of 2023, So Far
description: Our critics picked six films that you can catch up with over the long holiday.
content: As the summer may bring a little extra time to catch up on movies, our critics have selected a handful of options worth your time. All are available in theaters or on demand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darren Incorvaia
title: You Really Are a Tick Magnet
description: By studying how the arachnids respond to static electricity, researchers may have found a new reason to dread the bloodsucking creatures.
content: Most people try, or at least hope, to avoid ticks. The tiny arachnids spread a variety of harmful diseases, as they expand their range to new areas. But two scientists recently set out on a counterintuitive mission to collect as many bloodsucking ticks as possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Ancient Art or Fashion Forward? Both, Says a Top Batik Designer
description: Josephine Komara has redefined a cultural expression that was intricate and lovely but so locked in tradition it bordered on staid. “Tradition is the way we are,” she says. “Modern is the way we think.”
content: Josephine Komara was depressed. She had recently divorced. She had moved into a small house. Her business supplying fabric for lampshades was lucrative but unfulfilling. Ms. Komara sipped her wine and smoked a cigarette. She sank to the floor, dipping her hands into two wooden chests filled with antique Indonesian textiles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darren Walker
title: Repeal of Affirmative Action Is Only the Beginning
description: Opponents of diversity are opponents of any racial consciousness. They want to prevent us from understanding the ways that the past informs the present.
content: Let’s be honest about the painful reality: America has functioned as a full democracy — guaranteeing the franchise to all — for less than one human lifetime. In practice, our democracy is younger than me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: A Culinary Roman Empire’s Next Conquest? Manhattan.
description: The influential Roscioli family — purveyors of some of the best food in Italy — is finally bringing their buzzy pastas to the New World.
content: For decades, people in search of the best food in Rome have found their way into the arms of the Roscioli family. Atop a network of wine cellars between the ancient Jewish quarter and the Campo de’ Fiori flower market, descendants of Marco and Franco Roscioli run four businesses, each outstanding in its field: a bread bakery, a pastry shop, a wine bar and a salumeria moonlighting as a restaurant that has become one of most sought-after tables in the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The Supreme Court Delivered Two Big Rulings
description: Also, there were more clashes in France. Here's the latest at the end of Friday.
content: The Supreme Court’s six-member conservative supermajority imposed its authority today in a pair of major decisions that were applauded by the right and denounced by the White House. In both cases, the three liberal justices offered vigorous dissents.

author: By Devika Girish

description: This month’s picks include a visually stunning documentary about garbage, a lesbian comedy from Spain, a drama about a Bollywood-obsessed teen in 1980s Afghanistan and more.
content: This documentary by Nikolaus Geyrhalter is something of a visual oxymoron: it is a visually gorgeous, even pristine, movie about, well, garbage. The Austrian filmmaker weaves together observational portraits of trash and its handlers from across the world, from immigrant cleaners at an island resort in the Maldives, to a mechanized sorting plant in Austria, to volunteers who pick up after Burning Man in the Nevada desert. But this is no navel-gazing exercise in aestheticizing detritus or finding beauty in ugly places. Rather, Geyrhalter’s keen, rigorous tableaux provoke us to think about the massive global industry required to deal with the rubbish we so casually generate in our everyday culture of disposability.

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Alan Arkin Could Do It All. In ‘Glengarry Glen Ross,’ He Did.
description: The actor’s distinguished career is best captured by the humanity in his portrayal of a real estate salesman in the 1992 film written by David Mamet.
content: When news broke that the venerable character actor Alan Arkin had died Thursday at 89, he was remembered for roles onstage (“Enter Laughing,” his Broadway debut, for which he received a Tony Award), on the big screen (his Oscar-winning performance in “Little Miss Sunshine”) and on television (his Emmy-nominated turn on “The Kominsky Method”). But Arkin’s finest performance, and one that holds the key to his considerable gifts as both an actor and screen presence, may well be his appearance as a busted-out real estate salesman in the 1992 film adaptation of “Glengarry Glen Ross,” the Pulitzer Prize-winning drama by David Mamet. The picture came at a fallow point in Arkin’s career; much of his work in the previous decade had been in underseen comedies. He was billed fifth, behind Al Pacino, Jack Lemmon, Alec Baldwin and Ed Harris, and it was easy to regard him, at that moment, as a comparative lightweight — until you took in his wounded, affecting performance.

content: Alan Arkin, who won a Tony Award for his first lead role on Broadway, received an Academy Award nomination for his first feature film, and went on to have a long and diverse career as a character actor who specialized in comedy but was equally adept at drama, died on Thursday in San Marcos, Calif. He was 89.

content: In its 75-year history, Le Journal du Dimanche, France’s leading Sunday newspaper, has almost never missed publication. content: Peg Yorkin, a feminist activist and philanthropist who as a founder of the Feminist Majority, a national women’s rights organization, campaigned to bring mifepristone, the abortion pill, to the United States and to increase the number of women in political office, died on Sunday at her home in Malibu, Calif. author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and the Coalition of the Distrustful
description: The people who believe he is going to save America.
content: Before Covid, Gabe Whitney, a 41-year-old from West Bath, Maine, didn’t think much about vaccines. He wasn’t very political — he didn’t vote in 2020, he said, because he thought Donald Trump was a “psycho” and Joe Biden was “corrupt.” It wasn’t until the pandemic that Whitney started regularly watching the news, but as he did, he felt that things weren’t adding up. He doubted what he called “the narrative” and struggled with the hostility his questions about vaccines and other mitigations elicited from those close to him. He described being “blamed and labeled as someone who’s part of the problem because you’re questioning. Like not taking a stance on it, but just questioning. That was the worst.”

author: By Evan Moffitt
title: Pippa Garner’s Wild Ride
description: Long underestimated as a madcap provocateur, the conceptual artist is, at 81, finally being taken seriously.
content: High-heeled roller skates, a palm-frond umbrella and a shower in a can — these are just a few of Pippa Garner’s hundreds of inventions. For the past 50 years, the artist has been satirizing U.S. consumer habits with designs that are not always entirely useful. Few things have escaped her restless, imaginative tinkering, from automobiles to her own body, which she began, in her words, “gender-hacking” in the mid-1980s. That may be why the art world establishment long treated Garner, 81, as a fringe character, more madcap inventor than conceptual artist in the tradition of Marcel Duchamp or Andy Warhol.

title: Putin Thinks He’s Still in Control. He’s Not.
description: His system of rule simply can’t go on much longer.
content: The Scarlet Sails festival is one of Russia’s most popular holidays. A celebration of high school graduates held in St. Petersburg, it culminates in a spectacular light show, in which ships — including one with scarlet sails — pass along the Neva River, fireworks cracking above them. Teenagers mill about the city and drink on the banks of the river while members of the Russian elite, officials and oligarchs alike, congregate to drink champagne on their luxurious yachts. No one enjoys the occasion more than President Vladimir Putin, who loves this student holiday in his hometown and never misses a private party on the river, watching the ships go by.

content: Last weekend, in the course of about 36 hours, Vladimir Putin faced — and then survived — one of the most serious challenges to his rule in over 20 years. An armed rebellion led by Yevgeny Prigozhin, the head of a Russian mercenary group, took control of a southern military town, and then advanced toward Moscow, coming within about 125 miles of the city. Then, as suddenly as the rebellion began, it was over: Prigozhin was quickly exiled to Belarus without facing criminal charges — an outcome that shocked many Russia watchers.
